sp.p: Ay, as, the Franch Education make us propre à tout; beside, Cousin, you must know to play the Fool is the Science in France, and I diddè go to the Italian Academy at Paris thrice a week to learn to play de Fool of Signior Scaramouchè who is the most excellent Personage in the World for dat Noble Science. Angel is a dam English Fool to him.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Methinks now Angel is a very good Fool.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nauh, nauh, Nokes is a better Fool, but indeed the Englis' are not fit to be Fools; here are ver few good Fools. 'Tis true, you have many a young Cavalier, who go over into France to learn to be the Buffoon; but for all dat, dey return but mauvais Buffoon. Jarniè.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: I'm sure, Cousin, you have lost no time there.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Auh lè bravè Scaramouchè.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: But is it a Science in France, Cousin? and is there an Academy for Fooling: sure none go to it but Players.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Dey are Comedians dàt are de Matrès, but all the beaux monde go to learn, as they do here of Angel and Nokes; for if you did go abroad into Company, you wou'd find the best almost of de Nation conning in all places the Lessons which dey have learnt of the Fools, dere Matrès, Nokes and Angel.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Yes, yes, dey are the Gens de quality that practise dat Science most, and the most ambitieux; for Fools and Buffoons have been always most welcome to Courts, and desir'd in all Companies. Auh to be de Fool, de Buffoon, is to be de greatè Personagè.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Fools have Fortune, they say indeed.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: So say old Senequè.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Well, Cousin (not to make you proud) you are the greatest Fool in England, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Non, non, de gracè, non, Nokes dè Comedian is a pretty man, a pretty man for a Comedian, da—

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: You are modest, Cousin; but least my Father shou'd come in presently (which he will do as soon as he knows you are here) I must give you a Caution, which 'tis fit you shou'd have before you see him.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Vel, vèl, Cousin, vat is dat?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p:
You must know then (as commonly the conclusion of all mirth is sad) after I had a good while pleas'd my self in jesting and leading the poor Gentleman you sent into a Fools Paradise, and almost made him believe I wou'd go
away with him, my Father coming home this morning, came in upon us, and caught him with me.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Mala-pes • e.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: And drew his Sword upon him, and wou'd have kill'd him; for you know my Father's Spanish fierceness and jealousie.

sp.speaker: Mons▪
sp.p: But, how did he come off then? testè nòn.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: In short, I was fain to bring him off by saying he was my Dancingmaster.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Hah, ha, ha, vèr good Jestè.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: I was unwilling to have the poor man kill'd you know for our foolish Frolick with him; but then upon my Aunts and Fathers inquiry, how he came in, and who sent him; I was forc'd to say you did, desiring I shou'd be able to dance a Corant before our Wedding.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: A vèr good Jest—da—still bettrè as bettrè.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Now all that I am to desire of you, is to own you sent him, that I may not be caught in a lye.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Yes, yes, a ver good Jest, Gerrard, a Mastrè dè Dance, hah, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Nay, the Jest is like to be better yet; for my Father himself has oblig'd him now to come and teach me: So that now he must take the Dancingmaster upon him, and come three or four times come before our Wedding, lest my Father, if he shou'd come no more, shou'd be suspicious I had told him a lye: and (for ought I know) if he shou'd know o • but guess he were not a Dancingmaster, in his Spanish strictness and Punctillioes of Honour he might kill me as the shame and stain of his Honour and Family▪ which he talks of so much. Now you know the jealous cruel Fathers in Spain serve their poor innocent Daughters often so, and he is more than a Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Non, non, fear noting, I warrant you he shall come as often as you will to the House, and your Father shall never know who he is till we are marry'd; but then I'll tell him all for the Jests sake.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: But will you keep my Counsel, dear Cousin, till we are marry'd?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Poor▪ dear Fool, I warrant thee, mon soy.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Nay, what a Fool am I indeed, for you wou'd not have me kill'd: you love me too well sure, to be an Instrument of my death;
sp.stage: Enter Don Diego walking gravely, a little Black behind him. Mrs. Caution.]
sp.p: But here comes my Father, remember.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I would no more tell him of it, than I would tell you if I had been with a Weach, Jarnie—she's afraid to be kill'd, poor Wretch, and he's a capricious jealous Fop enough to do't, but here he comes.
I'll keep thy Counsel I warrant thee, my dear Soul, mon petit Coeùr.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Peace, peace, my Father's coming this way.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I, but by his march he won't be near enough to hear us this half hour, hah, ha, ha.

div.stage: Don Diego walks leisurely round the Monsieur, surveying him, and shrugging up his shoulders whilst Monsieur makes Legs and Faces.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Is that thing my▪ Cousin, Sister?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: 'Tis he, Sir.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Cousin, I am sorry to see you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Is that a Spanish Complement?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: So much disguis'd, Cousin.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Oh! is it out at last, ventrè?
Serviteur, Serviteur, à Monseur mon Oncle, and I am glad to see you here within doors, most Spanish Oncle, ha, ha, ha. But I should be sorry to see you in the streets, teste non.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Why soh—would you be asham'd of me, hah—(voto a St. Jago) wou'd you? hauh—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I it may be you wou'd be asham'd your self, Monseur mon Oncle, of the great Train you wou'd get to wait upon your Spanish Hose, puh—the Boys wou'd follow you, and hoot at you (vert and bleu) pardonè my Franch Franchise, Monsieur mon Oncle.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: We shall have sport anon, betwixt these two Contraries.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Do'st thou call me Monseur (voto a St. Jago▪ )

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: No, I did not call you Monseur voto a St. Jago, Sir, I know you are my Uncle Mr. James Formal—da—

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: But I can hardly know you are my Cousin, Mr. Nathaniel Paris; but call me Sir Don Diego henceforward, look you, and no Monsieur, call me Monsieur Guarda.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I confess my errour, Sir; for none but â blind man wou'd call you Monsieur, ha, ha, ha - But pray do not call me neder Paris, but de Paris, de Paris (si vou plai'st) Monseur de Paris! Call me Monseur and welcome, da—

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Monsieur de Pantaloòns then voto—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Monsieur de Pantalloons! a pretty name, a pretty name, ma foy, da—bein trove de Pantalloons; how much betrè dèn your de la Fountaines, de la Rivieres, de la Roches, and all the De's in France—da—well; but have you not the admiration for my Pantalloon, Don Diego mon Oncle?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I am astonish'd at them verde deramentè, they are wonderfully ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Redicule, redicule! ah—'tis well you are my Uncle, da—Redicule, ah—is dere any ting in de Universe so jenti as de Pantalloons? any ting so ravisaunt as de Pantalloons? Auh—I cou'd kneel down and varship a pair of jenti Pantalloons? vat, vat, you wou'd have me have de admiration for dis outward skin of your Thigh, which you call Spanish Hose, fie, fie, fie—ha, ha, ha▪

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Do'st thou deride my Spanish Hose? young Man, hauh.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: In comparison of Pantalloon I do undervalue 'em indeet, Don Diegue mon Oncle, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Thou art then a gavanho de malo gusto, look you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: You may call me vat you vill, Oncle Don Diegue; but I must needs say, your Spanish Hose are scurvy Hose, ugly Hose, lousie Hose, and stinking Hose.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Do not provoke me, Boracho.

div.stage: Puts his hand to his Sword.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Indeet for lousie I recant dat Epithete, for dere is scarce room in 'em for dat little Animal, ha, ha, ha. But for stinking Hose, dat Epithete may stand; for how can dey chuse but stink, since dey are so furieusmentè close to your Spanish Tail, da▪

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Do not provoke me, I say, En horâ malâ.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nay, Oncle, I am sorry you are in de pation; but I must live and dye for de Pantalloon against de Spanish Hose, da.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: You are a rash young Man, and while you wear Pantalloons, you are beneath my passion, voto—Auh—they make thee look and waddle (with all those gew-gaw Ribbons) like a great old Fat, slovenly Water-dog.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: And your Spanish Hose, and your Nose in the Air, make you look like a great grisled-long-Irish-Grey-hound, reaching a Crust off from a high Shelf, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Bueno, Bueno.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Caut.
sp.p: What have you a mind to ruine your self, and break off the Match?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Pshaw—wat do you telle me of the Matchè? deè tinke I will not vindicate Pantalloons, Morbleu?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Well! he is a lost young Man, I see, and desperately far gone in the Epidemick Malady of our Nation, the affectation of the worst of French Vanities: but I must be wiser than him, as I am a Spaniard look you Don Diego, and endeavour to reclaim him by Art and fair means (look you, Don Diego) if not, he shall never marry my Daughter look you, Don Diego, though he be my own Sister's Son, and has two thousand five hundred seventy three pound Starling twelve shillings and two pence a year Penny-rent, Segouaramentè.
Come, Young-man, since you are so obstinate, we will refer our difference to Arbitration, your Mistress my Daughter shall be Umpire betwixt us, concerning Spanish Hose and Pantalloons.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Pantalloons and Spanish Hose (si vous plaist.)

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Your Mistress is the fittest Judge of your Dress, sure?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I know ver vel, dat most of the Jeunesse of England will not change the Ribband upon de Crevat widout the consultation of dere Matress, but I am no Anglois da—nor shall I make de reference of my Dress to any in the Universe, da—I judg'd by any in England, teste non▪ I wou'd not be judg'd by an English Looking-glass, Jarnie.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Be not positivo, Young-man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Caut.
sp.p: Nay, pray refer it, Cousin, pray do.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Non, non, your Servant, your Servant, Aunt.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: But pray be not so positive, come hither, Daughter, tell me which is best.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Indeed, Father, you have kept me in universal ignorance, I know nothing.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: And do you tink I shall refer an Affair of dat consequence to a poor young ting who have not see the Varld, da, I am wiser than so voto?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Well, in short, if you will not be wiser, and leave off your French Dress, Stammering, and Tricks, look you, you shall be a Fool and go without my Daughter, voto.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: How, must I leave off my Janti Franch Accoustrements, and speak base Englis too, or not marry my Cousin! mon Oncle Don Diego▪ Do not break off the Match, do not; for know I will not leave off my Pantalloon and Franch Pronuntiation for ne'er a Cousin in England't, da.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I tell you again, he that marry's my Daughter shall at least look like a wise Man, for he shall wear the Spanish Habit, I am a Spanish Positivo.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ver vèl, ver vèl! and I am a Franch Positivo.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Then I am Definitivo; and if you do not go immediately into your Chamber, and put on a Spanish Habit, I have brought over on purpose for your Wedding Cloaths, and put off all these French Fopperies and Vanidades, with all your Grimaces, Agreeables, Adorables, ma Foys, and Jernies. I swear you shall never marry my Daughter (and by an Oath by Spaniard never broken) by my Whiskers and Snuff-box.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: O hold, do not swear, Uncle, for I love your Daughter furieusmènt.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: If you love her, you'll obey me.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Auh, wat vil become of me! but have the consideration, must I leave off all the Franch Beautes, Graces, and Embellisemènts, bote of my Person and Language.

div.stage: Exeunt Hipp. Mrs. Caution, and Prue laughing.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I will have it so.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I am ruinne den undonne, have some consideration for me, for dere is not the least Ribbon of my Garniture, but is as dear to me as your Daughter, Jernie—

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Then you do not deserve her, and for that reason I will be satisfi'd you love her better, or you shall not have her, for I am positivo.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Vil you breake mine Arte! pray have de consideration for me.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I say agen, you shall be dress'd before night from Top to Toe in the Spanish Habit, or you shall never marry my Daughter, look you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: If you will not have de consideration for me, have de consideration for your Daughter; for she have de passionate Amour for me, and like me in dis Habite betre den in yours, da—

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What I have said I have said, and I am uno Positivo.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Will you not so mush as allow me one little Franch Oate?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: No, you shall look like a Spaniard, but speak and swear like an English man, look you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Helas, helas, den I shall take my leave, mort, teste, ventre, Jernie, teste-bleu, ventre-bleu, ma foy, certes.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Pedro, Sanchez, wait upon this Cavaliero into his Chamber with those things I ordered you to take out of the Trunks, I wou'd have you a little accustomed to your Cloaths before your Wedding; for if you comply with me, you shall marry my Daughter to morrow, look you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Adieu then, dear Pantalloon! dear Beltè! dear Sword! dear Perruque! and dear Chappeaux, Retrouseè, and dear Shoe, Jernie; adieu, adieu, adieu, helas, helas, helas, will you have yet no pity.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I am a Spanish Positivo, look you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: And more cruel than de Spanish Inquisitiono, to compel a Man to a Habit against his Conscience, helas, helas, helas.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Here is the Dancing-master, shall I call my Mistress, Sir?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Yes. O you are as punctual as a Spaniard: I love your punctual Men, nay, I think 'tis before your time something.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Nay, I am resolv'd your Daughter, Sir, shall lose no time by my fault.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: So, so, 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I were a very unworthy Man, if I should not be punctual with her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: You speak honestly, very honestly, Friend; and I believe a very honest man, though a Dancing-master.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I am very glad you think me so, Sir.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What you are but a Young-man, are you marry'd yet?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No, Sir, but I hope I shall, Sir, very suddenly, if things hit right.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What the old Folks her Friends are wary, and cannot agree with you so soon as the Daughter can?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, the Father hinders it a little at present; but the Daughter I hope is resolv'd, and then we shall do well enough.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What! you do not steal her, according to the laudable Custom of some of your Brother Dancing-masters?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No, no, Sir, steal her, Sir, steal her, you are pleas'd to be merry, Sir, ha, ha, ha. I cannot but laugh at that question.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: No, Sir, methinks you are pleas'd to be merry; but you say the Father does not consent.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Not yet, Sir; but 'twill be no matter whether he does or no.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Was she one of your Scholars? if she were, 'tis a hundred to ten but you steal her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I shall not be able to hold laughing.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I find by your laughing you steal her, she was your Scholar, was she not?

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.p: Yes, Sir, she was the first I ever had, and may be the last too; for she has a Fortune (if I can get her) will keep me from teaching to dance any more.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: So, so, then she is your Scholar still it seems, and she has a good Portion, I am glad on't, nay, I knew you stole her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: My laughing may give him suspicions, yet I cannot hold.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What, you laugh I warrant to think how the young Baggage and you will mump the poor old Father; but if all her dependance for a Fortune be upon the Father, he may chance to mump you both, and spoil the Jest.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I hope it will not be in his power, Sir, ha, ha, ha.
I shall laugh too much anon.

Pray, Sir, be pleas'd to call for your Daughter, I am impatient till she comes; for time was never more precious with me and with her too, it ought to be so, sure, since you say she is to be marry'd to morrow.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: She ought to bestir her, as you say indeed, wuh, Daughter, Daughter, Prue, Hippolita: Come away, Child, why do you stay so long?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Your Servant, Master! indeed I am asham'd you have stay'd for me.

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.p: O good Madam, 'tis my Duty, I know you came as soon as you cou'd.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: I knew my Father was with you, therefore I did not make altogether so much haste as I might; but if you had been alone, nothing shou'd have kept me from you, I wou'd not have been so rude as to have made you stay a minute for me, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, fidle, faddle, what a deal of Ceremony there is betwixt your Dancing-master and you, Querno—

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, I hope you'll allow me to shew my respect to my Master, for I have a great respect for my Master.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And I am very proud of my Scholar, and am a very great Honourer of my Scholar.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, come, Friend, about your bus'ness, and honour the King. Your Dancing-masters and Barbers are such finical smooth-tongu'd, tatling Fellows, and if you set 'em once a talking, they'll ne'er a done, no more than when you set 'em a fidling: indeed all that deal with Fiddles are given to impertinency.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Well! well! this is an impertinent Fellow, without being a Dancingmaster: he's no more a Dancing-master than I am a Maid.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What! will you still be wiser than I? voto.
Come, come about with my Daughter, Man.

sp.speaker: Prue.
sp.p: So he wou'd, I warrant you, if your Worship wou'd let him alone.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: How now Mrs. Nimble-Chaps?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Well, though I have got a little Canting at the Dancing-School since I was here, yet I do all so bunglingly, he'll discover me.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Try, come take my hand, Master.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Look you, Brother, the impudent Harletry gives him her hand.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Can he dance with her without holding her by the hand?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Here, take my hand, Master.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I wish it were for good and all.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: You Dancing-masters are always so hasty, so nimble.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Voto a St. Jago, not that I can see, about, about with her, Man.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I cannot about with her as I wou'd do, unless you will please to go out a little, Sir; for I see she is bashful still before you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Hey, hey, more fooling yet, come, come, about with her.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Nay, indeed, Father, I am asham'd and cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: But you shall help it, for I will not stir: move her, I say begin Hussie, move when he'll have you.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I cannot but laugh at that, ha, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Come then, Madam, since it must be so let us try, but I shall discover all, One, two, and Coupee.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Nay de' see how he squeezes her hand, Brother, O the lewd Villain!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, move, I say, and mind her not.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: One, two, three, four, and turn round.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: De' see again he took her by the bare Arm.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, move on, she's mad.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: One, two, and a Coupee.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, one, two, turn out your Toes.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: There, there, he pinch'd her by the Thigh, will you suffer it?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: One, two, three, and fall back.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Fall back, fall back, back, some of you are forward enough to fall back.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Back, Madam.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Fall back when he bids you, Hussie.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: How! how! fall back, fall back, marry, but she shall not fall back when he bids her.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I say she shall, Huswife, come.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: She will, she will, I warrant you, Sir, if you won' be angry with her.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Do you know what he means by that now, you a Spaniard?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: How's that, I not a Spaniard? say such a word again.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Come forward, Madam, three steps agen.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: See, see, she squeezes his hand now, O the debauch'd Harletry!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: So, so, mind her not, she moves forward pretty well; but you must move as well backward as forward, or you'll never do any thing to purpose.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Do you know what you say, Brother, your self now? are you at your beastliness before your young Daughter?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: How now, Mistress, are you so merry? is this your staid Maid as you call her, Sister impertinent?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I have not much to say to you, Miss; but I shall not have an opportunity to do it, unless we can get your Father out.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come about agen with her.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Look you, there she squeezes his hand hard again.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Indeed and indeed, Father, my Aunt puts me quite out, I cannot dance while she looks on for my heart, she makes me asham'd and afraid together.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Indeed if you wou'd please to take her out, Sir, I am sure I shou'd make my Scholar do better, than when you are present, Sir, pray, Sir, be pleased for this time to take her away; for the next time I hope I shall order it so, we shall trouble neither of you.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: No, no, Brother, stir not, they have a mind to be left alone. Come, there's a beastly Trick in't: he's no Dancing-master I tell you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Damn'd Jade, she'll discover us.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What will you teach me? nay then I will go out, and you shall go out too, look you.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I will not go out, look you.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, come, thou art a censorious wicked Woman, and you shall disturb them no longer.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: What will you bawd for your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ay, ay, come go out, out, out.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I will not go out, I will not go out, my Conscience will not suffer me; for I know by experience what will follow.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir, we'll make good use of our time when you are gone.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Do you hear him again, don't you know what he means?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, you are a fine Gentleman to abuse my poor Father so.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: 'Tis but by your Example, Miss.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Well I am his Daughter, and may m ••• the bolder with him, I hope.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And I am his Son-in-law, that shall 〈…〉 nd therefore may claim my Priviledge too of making bold with him, I hope.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Methinks you shou'd be contented in making bold with his Daughter; for you have made very bold with her, sure.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I hope I shall make bolder with her yet.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: I do not doubt your confidence, for you are a Dancing-master.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why, Miss? I hope you wou'd not have me a fine senseless Whining, modest Lover; for modesty in a Man is as ill as the want of it in a Woman.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: I thank you for that, Sir, how you have made bold with me indeed; but if I am such a confident Piece, I am sure you made me so; if you had not had the confidence to come in at the Window, I had not had the confidence to look upon a Man: I am sure I cou'd not look upon a Man before.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But that I humbly conceive, sweet Miss, was your Fathers fault, because you had not a Man to look upon. But, dearest Miss, I do not think you confident, you are only innocent; for that which would be called confidence, nay impudence in a Woman of years, is called innocency in one of your age; and the more impudent you appear, the more innocent you are thought.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Say you so! has Youth such Priviledges? I do not wonder then most Women seem impudent, since it is to be thought younger than they are it seems; but indeed, Master you are as great an Encourager of impudence I see, as if you were a Dancing master in good earnest.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Yes, yes, a young thing may do anything, may leap out of the Window, and go away with her Dancing-master, if she please.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: So, so, the use follows the Doctrine very suddenly.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Well, Dearest, pray let us make the use we shou'd of it, lest your Father shou'd make too bold with us, and come in before we wou'd have him.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Indeed old Relations are apt to take that ill bred freedom of pressing into young Company at unseasonable hours.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Come, dear Miss, let me tell you how I have design'd matters; for in talking of anything else we lose time and opportunity: people abroad indeed say the English Women are the worst in the World in using an opportunity, they love tittle tattle and Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: 'Tis because I warrant opportunities are not so scarce here as abroad, they have more here than they can use; but let people abroad say what they will of English Women, because they do not know 'em, but what say people at home?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Pretty Innocent, ha, ha, ha. Well I say you will not make use of your opportunity.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: I say you have no reason to say so yet.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Well, then anon at nine of the Clock at night I'll try you; for I have already bespoke a Parson, and have taken up the three back Rooms of the Tavern, which front upon the Gallery-window, that nobody may see us escape, and I have appointed (precisely betwixt eight and nine of the Clock when it is dark) a Coach and Six to wait at the Tavern-door for us.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: A Coach and Six, a Coach and Six, do you say? nay then I see you are resolv'd to carry me away▪ for a Coach and Six, though there were not a Man but the Coach-man with it, wou'd carry▪away any young Girl of my Age in England, a Coach and Six!

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Then you will be sure to be ready to go with me.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: What young Woman of the Town cou'd ever say no to a Coach and Six, unless it were going into the Country: a Coach and Six, 'tis not in the power of fourteen years old to resist it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: You will be sure to be ready?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: You are sure 'tis a Coach and Six?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I warrant you, Miss.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: I warrant you then they'll carry us merrily away▪ a Coach and Six?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But have you charm'd your Cousin the Monsieur (as you said you wou'd) that he in the mean time say nothing to prevent us?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: I warrant you.

div.stage: Enter to 'em Don Diego and Mrs. Caution pressing in.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I will come in.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Well, I hope by this time you have given her full instructions, you have told her what and how to do, you have done all.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: We have just done indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, we have just done, Sir.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: And I fear just undone, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: De' hear that damn'd Witch.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come leave your censorious prating, thou hast been a false right Woman thy self in thy Youth, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I right! I right! I scorn your words, I'd have you to know, and 'tis well known. I right! no 'tis your dainty Minx, that Jillflirt your Daughter here that is right, do you see how her Handkerchief is ruffled, and what a heat she's in?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: She has been dancing.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Adam and Eve's Dance, or the beginning of the World, de' see how she pants?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: She has not been us'd to motion.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Motion, motion, motion de' call it? no indeed, I kept her from motion till now, motion with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: You put the poor bashful Girl to the blush, you see, hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: 'Tis her guilt, not her modesty, marry.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, come, mind her not, Child, come, Master, let me see her dance now the whole Dance roundly together, come sing to her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Faith, we shall be discovered after all, you know I cannot sing a Note, Miss.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, come, Man.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Indeed, Father, my Master's In haste now, pray let it alone till anon at night, when you say he is to come again, and then you shall se me dance it to the Violin, pray stay till then, Father.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I will not be put off so, come begin.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Pray▪ Father.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, sing to her, come begin.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, excuse me till anon, I am in some haste.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I say begin, I will not excuse you, come take her by the hand, and about with her.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I say he shall not take her by the hand▪ he shall touch her no more; while I am here there shall be no more squeesing and tickling her palm, good Mr. Dancing-master, stand off.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Get you out, Mrs. Impertinence, take her by the hand, I say.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Stand off, I say, he shall not touch her, he has touch'd her too much already.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: If patience were not a Spanish Vertue, I wou'd lay it aside now. I say let 'em dance.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I say they shall not dance.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Pray, Father, since you see my Aunts obstinacy, let us alone till anon, when you may keep her out.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Well then, Friend, do not fail to come.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Nay, if he fail me at last.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Be sure you come, for she's to be marry'd to morrow, do you know it?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Sir, sweet Scholar, your humble Servant, till night, and think in the mean time of the instructions I have given you, that you may be the readier when I come.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I, Girl, be sure you do, and do you be sure to come.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: You need not be so concern'd, he'll be sure to come, I warrant you; but if I cou'd help it, he shou'd never set foot agen in the House.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: You wou'd frighten the poor Dancing-master from the House; but be sure you come for all her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.
But this Jade will pay me when I am gone.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, I must let you out, and I wish I cou'd keep you out. He a Dancing-master, he's a Chouce, a Cheat, a meer Cheat, and that you'll find.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I find any Man a Cheat! I cheated by any Man! I scorn your words, I that have so much Spanish Care, Circumspection, and Prudence, cheated by a Man: do you think I who have been in Spain, look you, and have kept up my Daughter a twelve-month, for fear of being cheated of her, look you? I cheated of her!

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Well, say no more.

div.stage: Exeunt Don, Hipp. Caut. and Prue.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Well, old Formality, if you had not kept up your Daughter, I am sure I had never cheated you of her.

lg.l: The wary Fool is by his care betray'd,
As Cuckolds by their Jealousie are made.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur de Paris without a Perruque, with a Spanish Hat, a Spanish Doublet, Stockins, and Shooes, but in Pantalloons, a Waste-Belt, and a Spanish Dagger in't, and a Crevat about his Neck.
Enter Hippolita and Prue behind laughing.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: TO see wat a Fool Love do make of one, Jernie. It do metamorphose de brave Man into de Beast, de Sotte, de Animal.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nay, you may laugh, 'tis ver vel, I am become as redicule for you as can be, mort-blue. I have deform my self into an ugly Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Why, do you call this disguising your self like a Spaniard while you wear Pantalloons still and the Crevat.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: But is here not the double Doublet and the Spanish Dagger aussy.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: But 'tis as long as the French Sword, and worn like it. But where's your Spanish Beard, the thing of most consequence?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Jernie, do you tink Beards are as easie to be had as in de Play-houses, non; but if here be no the ugly-long-Spanish Beard, here are, I am certain, the ugly▪ long-Spanish Ear.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: That's very true, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Auh de ingrate! dat de Woman is, when we poor men are your Gallants you laugh at us your selves, and wen we are your Husbands, you make all the Warld laugh at us, Jernie. Love, dam Love, it make the man more redicule than Poverty, Poetry, or a new Title of Honeur, Jernie.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What at your Jernies still? voto.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Why, Oncle, you are at your voto's still.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Nay, I'll allow you to be at your voto's too, but not to make the incongruous Match of Spanish Doublet and French Pantalloons.

div.stage: Holding his Hat before his Pantalloons.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nay, pray dear Oncle, let me unite France and Spain, 'tis the Mode of France now, Jarnie, voto.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Well, I see I must pronounce, I told you, if you were not drest in the Spanish Habit to night, you shou'd not marry my Daughter to morrow, look you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Well, am I not habiliee in de Spanish Habit, my Doublet, Ear, and Hat, Leg and Feet are Spanish, that dey are.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I told you I was a Spanish Positivo, voto.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Vil you not spare my Pantalloon (begar) I will give you one little finger to excuse my Pantalloon, da—

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I have said, look you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p:
Auch chere Pantalloons, speak for my Pantalloons, Cousin, my poor
Pantalloons are as dear to me as de Scarff to de Countree Capitaine, or de new made Officer; therefore have de compassion for my Pantalloons, Don Diego, mon Oncle, helas, helas, helas.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I have said, look you, your Dress must be Spanish, and your Language English, I am uno Positivo.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: And must speak base good English too, ah la pitiee, helas.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: It must be done, and I will see this great change e'er it be dark, voto—your time is not long, look to't, look you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Helas, helas, helas, dat Espaigne shou'd conquer la France in England, helas, helas, helas.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: You see what pains I take to make him the more agreeable to you, Daughter.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: But indeed and indeed, Father, you wash the Black-a-more white, in endeavouring to make a Spaniard of a Monsieur, nay an English Monsieur too, consider that, Father; for when once they have taken the French plie (as they call it) they are never to be made so much as English men again, I have heard say.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What, I warrant, you are like the rest of the young silly Baggages of England, that like nothing but what is French. You wou'd not have him reform'd, you wou'd have a Monsieur to your Husband, wou'd you, Querno?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: No indeed, Father, I wou'd not have a Monsieur to my Husband, not I indeed, and I am sure you'll never make my Cousin otherwise.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: You can't, you can't, indeed, Father: and you have sworn, you know, he shall never have me, if he does not leave off his Monsieurship. Now as I told you, 'tis as hard for him to cease being a Monsieur, as 'tis for you to break a Spanish Oath, so that I am not in any great danger of having a Monsieur to my Husband.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Well; but you shall have him for your Husband, look you.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Then you will break your Spanish Oath.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: No, I will break him of his French Tricks, and you shall have him for your Husband, Querno.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Indeed and indeed, Father, I shall not have him.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Indeed you shall, Daughter.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Well, you shall see, Father.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: No I warrant you, she will not have him, she'll have her Dancingmaster rather: I know her meaning, I understand her.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Thou malicious foolish Woman, you understand her! but I do understand her, she says I will not break my Oath, nor he his French Customs, so through our difference she thinks she shall not have him, but she shall.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: But I shan't.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I know she will not have him, because she hates him.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I tell you, if she does hate him, 'tis a sign she will have him for her Husband; for 'tis not one of a thousand that marries the man she loves, look you. Besides, 'tis all one whether she loves him now or not; for as soon as she's marry'd, she'd be sure to hate him: that's the reason we wise Spaniards are jealous and only expectè, nay will be sure our Wives shall fear us, look you.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Pray, good Father and Aunt, do not dispute about nothing, for I am sure he will never be my Husband to hate.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I am of your opinion indeed, I understand you, I can see as far as another.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: You, you cannot see so much as through your Spectacles, but I understand her, 'tis her meer desire to Marriage makes her say she shall not have him; for your poor young things, when they are once in the teens, think they shall never be marry'd.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Well, Father, think you what you will, but I know what I think.

div.stage: Enter Monsieur in the Spanish Habit entire only with a Crevat, and follow'd by the little Black-a-more with a Golilia in his hand.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, did not I tell you, you shou'd have him, look you there, he has comply'd with me, and is a perfect Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I am ugly Rogue enough, now sure, for my Cousin; but 'tis your Father's fault, Cousin, that you han't the handsomest best dress'd man in the Nation, a man be in mise.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Yet agen at your French? and a Crevat on still (voto a St. Jago) off, off with▪

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nay I will ever hereafter speak clownish good English, do but spare me my Crevat▪

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I am uno Positivo, look you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Let me not put on that Spanish Yoke, but spare me my Crevat; for I love Crevat furiesment.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Agen at your Furiesments!

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Indeed I have forgot my self, but have some mercy.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Off, off, off with it I say, come refuse the Ornamento principal of the Spanish Habit.

div.stage: Takes him by the Crevat, pulls it off, and the Black puts on the Golilia.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Will you have no mercy, no pity, alas, alas, alas, Oh I had rather put on the English Pillory than this Spanish Golilia, for 'twill be all a case I'm sure; for when I go abroad, I shall soon have a Crowd of Boys about me, peppering me with rotten Eggs and Turneps, helas, helas.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Helas again?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Alas, alas, alas.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: I shall dye; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I shall burst, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ay, ay, you see what I am come to for your sake; Cousin and Uncle, pray take notice how ridiculous I am grown to my Cousin that loves me above all the World? she can no more forbear laughing at me, I vow and swear, than if I were as arrant a Spaniard as your self.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Be a Spaniard like me, and ne'er think people laugh at you: there was never a Spaniard that thought any one laugh'd at him; but what do you laugh at a Golilia, Baggage? Come, Sirrah-Black, now do you teach him to walk with the verdadero gesto, gracia, and Gravidad of a true Castilian.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Must I have my Dancing-master too? come little Master then, lead on.

div.stage: Black struts about the Stage, the Monsieur follows him, imitating awkerdly all he does.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Malo, malo, with your Hat on your Pole, as if it hung upon a Pin; the French and English wear their Hats, as if their Horns would not suffer 'em to come over their Foreheads, voto—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: 'Tis true, there are some well-bred Gentlemen have so much Reverence for their Perruque, that they wou'd refuse to be Grandees of your Spain, for fear of putting on their Hats, I vow and swear.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, Black, teach him now to make a Spanish Leg.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, your Spanish Leg is an English Courtsie, I vow and swear, hah, hah, ha.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Well, the Hood does not make the Monk, the Ass was an Ass still, though he had the Lyons Skin on; this will be a light French Fool, in spight of the grave Spanis. Habit, look you. But, Black, do what you can, make the most of him, walk him about.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Here are the people, Sir, you sent to speak with about Provisions for the Wedding, and here are your Cloaths brought home too, Mistress.

div.stage: Prue goes to the door, and returns.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Well, I come: Black, do what you can with him, walk him about.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Indeed, Uncle, if I were as you, I would not have the grave Spanish Habit so travesty'd, I shall disgrace it and my little Black Master too, I vow and swear.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Learn, learn of him, improve your self by him, and do you walk him, walk him about soundly. Come, Sister and Daughter, I must have your Judgments, though I shall not need 'em, look you, walk him, see you walk him.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Jernie, he does not only make a Spaniard of me, but a Spanish Jennit, in giving me to his Lacquey to walk; but come a long, little Master.

div.stage: The Black instructs the Monsieur on one side of the Stage, Prue standing on the other.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: O the unfortunate condition of us poor Chamber-maids, who have all the carking and caring, the watching and sitting up, the trouble and danger of our Mistresses Intrigues! whilst they go away with all the pleasure; and if they can get their Man in a corner, 'tis well enough, they ne'er think of the poor watchful Chamber-maid, who sits knocking her heels in the cold, for want of better exercise in some melancholy Lobby or Entry, when she cou'd imploy her time every whit as well as her Mistress for all her Quality, if she were but put to't.

sp.speaker: Black.
sp.p: Hold up your head, hold up your head, Sir, a stooping Spaniard, Malo.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: True, a Spaniard scorns to look upon the ground.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: We can shift for our Mistresses, and not for our selves, mine has got a handsom proper Young-man, and is just going to make the most of him, whilst I must be left in the Lurch here with a Couple of ugly little Black-a-more Boys in Bonnets, and an old wither'd Spanish Eunuch, not a Servant else in the House, nor have I hopes of any comfortable Society at all.

sp.speaker: Black.
sp.p: Now let me see you make your Visit-Leg thus.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Auh, teste non, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Black
sp.p:
What, a Spaniard, and laugh aloud! no; if you laugh thus only so—now your Salutation in the street as you pass by your Acquaintance, look you,
thus—if to a Woman, thus, putting your Hat upon your heart; if to a man, thus with a nod, so—but frown a little more, frown. But if to a Woman you wou'd be very ceremonious too, thus—so—your Neck nearer your shoulder, so—Now if you wou'd-speak contemptibly of any man or thing, do thus with your hand—so—and shrug up your shoulders, till they hide your Ears. Now walk agen.

div.stage: The Black and the Monsieur walk off the Stage.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: All my hopes are in that Coxcomb there; I must take up with my Mistresses leavings, though we Chamber-maids are wont to be before-hand with them: but he is the dullest, modestest Fool, for a Frenchisi'd Fool, as ever I saw; for no body cou'd be more coming to him than I have been (though I say it) and yet I am ne'er the nearer. I have stollen away his Hankerchief, and told him of it, and yet he wou'd never so much as struggle with me to get it again. I have pull'd off his Perruque, unty'd his Ribbons, and have been very bold with him, yet he would never be so with me; nay, I have pinch'd him, punch'd him, and tickl'd him, and yet he would never do the like for me.

sp.speaker: Black.
sp.p: Nay, thus, thus, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: And to make my person more acceptable to him, I have us'd Art, as they say; for every night since he came, I have worn the Forehead-piece of Bees wax and Hogs-grease, and every morning wash'd with Butter-milk and wild Tansie, and have put on every day for his only sake my Sunday's Bow-dy-Stockins, and have new chalk'd my Shooes, and's constantly as the morning came; nay, I have taken an occasion to garter my Stockings before him, as if unawares of him; for a good Leg and Foot, with good Shooes and Stockings, are very provoking, as they say, but the Devil a bit wou'd he be provok'd; but I must think of a way.

sp.speaker: Black.
sp.p: Thus, thus.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: What so—well, well, I have Lessons enow for this time. Little Master, I will have no more, lest the multiplicity of'em make me forget'em, da—Prue, art thou there, and so pensive? what art thou thinking of?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Indeed I am asham'd to tell your Worship.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: What asham'd! wer't thou thinking then of my beastliness? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Nay, then I am forc'd to tell your Worship in my own vindication.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Come then.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: But indeed your Worship—I'm asham'd that I am, though it was nothing but a dream I had of your sweet Worship last night.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Of my sweet Worship! I warrant it was a sweet dream then, what was it? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Nay, indeed I have told your Worship enough already, you may guess the rest.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I cannot guess, ha, ha, ha, what shou'd it be? prethee let's know the rest.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Wou'd you have me so impudent?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Impudent! ha, ha, ha, nay prethee tell me, for I can't guess, da—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Nay, tis always so; for want of the mens guessing, the poor Women are forc'd to be impudent, but I am still asham'd.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I will know it, speak.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Why then methoughts last night you came up into my Chamber in your Shirt, when I was in Bed, and that you might easily do; for I have ne'er a Lock to my door: now I warrant I am red as my Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: No, thou'rt as yellow as e'er thou wert.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Yellow, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ay, ay; but let's hear the Dream out.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Why, can't you guess the rest now?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: No not I, I vow and swear, come let's hear.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: But can't you guess in earnest?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Not I, the Devil eat me.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Not guess yet! why then methoughts you came to bed to me? Now am I as red as my Petticoat again.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, well, and what then? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Nay, now I know by your Worship's laughing, you guess what you did: I'm sure I cry'd out, and wak'd all in tears, with these words in my mouth, You have undone me, you have undone me! your Worship has undone me.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Hah, ha, ha; but you wak'd and found it was but a Dream.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Indeed it was so lively, I know not whether 'twas a Dream or no: but if you were not there, I'll undertake you may come when you will, and do any thing to me you will, I sleep so fast.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: No, no, I don't believe that.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Indeed you may, your Worship—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Insensible Beast! he will not understand me yet, and one wou'd think I speak plain enough.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Well, but Prue, what art thou thinking of?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Of the Dream, whether it were a Dream or no.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: 'Twas a Dream I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Was it? I am hugeous glad it was a Dream.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ay, ay, it was a Dream; and I am hugeous glad it was a Dream too.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: But now I have told your Worship, my door hath neither Lock nor Latch to it: if you shou'd be so naughty as to come one night, and prove the dream true—I am so afraid on't.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ne'er fear it, dreams go by the contraries.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Then by that I should come into your Worship's Chamber, and come to bed to your Worship. Now am I as red as my Petticoat again, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: No, thou art no redder than a Brick unburnt, Prue.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: But if I shou'd do such a trick in my sleep, your Worship wou'd not censure a poor harmless Maid, I hope; for I am apt to walk in my sleep.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Well then, Prue, because thou shalt not shame thy self (poor Wench) I'll be sure to lock my door every night fast.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: So, so, this way I find will not do, I must come roundly and down-right to the bus'ness, like other Women, or—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: O the Dancing-master!

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Dear Sir, I have something to say to you in your Ear, which I am asham'd to speak aloud.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Another time, another time, Prue, but now go call your Mistress to her Dancing-master, go, go.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Nay, pray hear me, Sir, first.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Another time, another time, Prue, prethee be gone.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Nay, I beseech your Worship hear me.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: No, prethee be gone.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Nay, I am e'en well enough serv'd for not speaking my mind when I had an opportunity. Well, I must be playing the modest Woman, forsooth; a Womans hypocrisie in this case does only deceive her self.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: O the brave Dancing-master, the fine Dancing-master, your Servant, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir, I protest I did not know you at first. I am afraid this Fool shou'd spoil all, notwithstanding Hippolita's care and management, yet I ought to trust her; but a Secret is more safe with a treacherous Knave than a talkative Fool.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Come, Sir, you must know a little Brother Dancing-master of yours, Walking-master I shou'd have said; for he teaches me to walk and make Legs by the bye: Pray know him, Sir, salute him, Sir; you Christian Dancing-masters are so proud.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But, Monsieur, what strange Metamorphosis is this? you look like a Spaniard, and talk like an English-man again, which I thought had been impossible.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nothing impossible to Love, I must do't, or lose my Mistress your pretty Scholar, for 'tis I am to have her; you may remember I told you she was to be marry'd to a great man, a man of Honour and Quality.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But does she enjoyn you to this severe penance, such I am sure it is to you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: No, no, 'tis by the compulsion of the starch'd Fop her Father, who is so arrant a Spaniard, he wou'd kill you and his Daughter, if he knew who you were; therefore have a special care to dissemble well.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Dear Gerrard, go little Master and call my Cousin, tell her, her Dancing-master is here.

I say, Dear Gerrard, Faith I'm obliged to you for the trouble you have had: when I sent you, I intended a Jest indeed, but did not think it wou'd have been so dangerous a Jest; therefore pray forgive me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I do, do heartily forgive you

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: But can you forgive me, for sending you at first, like a Fool as I was, 'twas ill done of me; can you forgive me?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I do forgive you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p:
Well, thou art a generous man, I vow and swear, to come and take upon you this trouble, danger, and shame, to be thought a paltry Dancingmaster,
and all this to preserve a Ladies honour and life, who intended to abuse you; but I take the obligation upon me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Pish, pish, you are not obliged to me at all.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Faith but I am strangely obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Faith but you are not.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I vow and swear but I am.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I swear you are not.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nay, thou art so generous a Dancing-master—ha, ha, ha.

div.stage: Enter Don Diego, Hippolita, Caution, and Prue.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: You shall not come in, Sister.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I will come in.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: You will not be civil.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I'm sure they will not be civil, if I do not come in, I must, I will.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Well, honest Friend, you are very punctual, which is a rare Vertue in a Dancing-master, I take notice of it, and will remember it, I will, look you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: So silly-damn'd-politick Spanish Uncle, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: My fine Scholar, Sir, there, shall never have reason (as I told you) Sir, to say I am not a punctual man, for I am more her Servant than to any Scholar I ever had.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Well said, • 'faith, thou dost make a pretty Fool of him, I vow and swear; but I wonder people can be made such Fools of, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Well, Master, I thank you, and I hope I shall be a grateful kind Scholar to you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, cunning little Jilt, what a Fool she makes of him too: I wonder people can be made such Fools of, I vow and swear, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Indeed it shall go hard but I'll be a grateful kind Scholar to you.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: As kind as ever your Mother was to your Father, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: How; agen with your senseless suspicions.

sp.speaker: Mons▪
sp.p: Pish, pish, Aunt, ha, ha, ha, she's a Fool another way; she thinks she loves him, ha, ha, ha. Lord, that people shou'd be such Fools!

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Come, come, I cannot but speak, I tell you beware in time; for he is no Dancing-master, but some debauch'd person who will mump you of your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Will you be wiser than I still? Mump me of my Daughter! I wou'd I cou'd see any one mump me of my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: And mump you of your Mistress too, young Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, will you be wiser than I too, voto. Mump me of my Mistress! I wou'd I cou'd see any one mump me of my Mistress.
I am afraid this damn'd old Aunt shou'd discover us, I vow and swear; be careful therefore and resolute.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: He, he does not go about his bus'ness like a Dancing-master, he'll ne'er teach her to dance, but he'll teach her no goodness soon enough I warrant: he a Dancing-master!

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I, the Devil eat me, if he be not the best Dancing-master in England now. Was not that well said, Cousin? was it not? for he's a Gentleman Dancing-master, you know.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: You know him, Cousin, very well, Cousin, you sent him to my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Uncle, know him!
We'll ne'er be discovered, I warrant, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: But will you be made a Fool of too?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Aunt, ne'er trouble your self.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, Friend, about your bus'ness, about with my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Nay, pray, Father, be pleas'd to go out a little, and let us but practise a while, and then you shall see me dance the whole Dance to the Violin.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Tittle, tattle, more fooling still! did not you say when your Master was here last, I shou'd see you dance to the Violin when he came agen.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: So I did, Father; but let me practise a little first before, that I may be perfect. Besides, my Aunt is here, and she will put me out, you know I cannot dance before her.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Fiddle, faddle.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: They're afraid to be discovered by Gerard's bungling, I see. Come, come, Uncle, turn out, let 'em practise.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I won't (voto a St. Jago) what a fooling's here?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Come, come, let 'em practise, turn out, turn out, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Why, can't she practise it before me?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Come, Dancers and Singers are sometimes humorsom; besides, 'twill be more grateful to you, to see it danc'd all at once to the Violin. Come, turn out, turn out, I say.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What a fooling's here still amongst you, voto?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: So there he is with you, voto, turn out, turn out, I vow and swear you shall turn out.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Well, shall I see her dance it to the Violin at last?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Sir, what do you think I teach her for?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Go, go, turn out, and you too, Aunt.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Seriously, Nephew, I shall not budge, royally I shall not.

sp.speaker: Mons▪
sp.p: Royally you must, Aunt, come.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Pray hear me, Nephew.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I will not hear you.

sp.speaker: Caut
sp.p: 'Tis for your sake I stay, I must not suffer you to be wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Come, no wheedling, Aunt, come away.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: That slippery Fellow will do't.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Let him do't.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Indeed he will do't, royally he will.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Well let him do't, royally.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: He will wrong you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Well, let him, I say, I have a mind to be wrong'd, what's that to you, I will be wrong'd, if you go thereto, I vow and swear.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: You shall not be wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: You shall not.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What's the matter? won't she be rul'd? come, come away, you shall not disturb 'em.

div.stage: Don and Monsieur thrust Caution out.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: De' see how they laugh at you both, well go to, the Troth telling Trojan Gentlewoman of old was ne'er believ'd, till the Town was taken, rumag'd, and ransak'd, even even so—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Hah, hah, ha, turn out. Lord, that people shou'd be such arrant Cuddens, ha, ha, ha; But I may stay, may I not?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: No, no, I'd have you go out and hold the door, Cousin, or else my Father will come in agen before his time.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I will, I will then, sweet Cousin, 'twas well thought on, that was well thought on indeed for me to hold the door.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: But be sure you keep him out, Cousin, till we knock.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I warrant you, Cousin, Lord, that people shou'd be made such Fools of, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: So, so, to make him hold the door, while I steal his Mistress is not unpleasant.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Ay, but wou'd you do so ill a thing, so treacherous a thing? Faith 'tis not well.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Faith I can't help it. Since 'tis for your sake, come, Sweetest, is not this our way into the Gallery?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Yes, but it goes against my Conscience to be accessary to so ill a thing; you say you do it for my sake?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Alas, poor Miss! 'tis not against your Conscience, but against your modesty, you think to do it franckly.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Nay, if it be against my modesty too, I can't do it indeed.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Come, come, Miss, let us make haste, all's ready.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Nay, Faith, I can't satisfie my scruple.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Come, Dearest, this is not a time for scruples nor modesty; modesty between Lovers is as impertinent as Ceremony between Friends, and modesty is now as unseasonable as on the Wedding night: come away, my Dearest.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Nay sure, we have lost too much time already: Is that a proper Question now? if you wou'd know, come along, for I have all ready.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: But I am not ready.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Truly, Miss, we shall have your Father come in upon us, and prevent us again, as he did in the morning.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: 'Twas well for me he did; for on my Conscience if he had not come in, I had gone clear away with you when I was in the humour.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Come, Dearest, you wou'd frighten me as if you were not yet in the same humour. Come, come away, the Coach and Six is ready.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: 'Tis too late to take the Air, and I am not ready.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: You were ready in the morning.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: I, so I was.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Come, come, Miss, indeed the Jest begins to be none.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: What, I warrant you think me in jest then?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: In jest, certainly, but it begins to be troublesom

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p:
But, Sir, you cou'd believe I was in earnest in the morning, when I but seemed to be ready to go with you; and why won't you believe me now,
when I declare to the contrary? I take it unkindly, that the longer I am acquainted with you, you shou'd have the less confidence in me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake, Miss, lose no more time thus, your Father will come in upon us, as he did—

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Let him, if he will.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: He'll hinder our design.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: No, he will not, for mine is to stay here now.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Are you in earnest?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: You'll find it so.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How! why you confess'd but now you wou'd have gone with me in the morning.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: I was in the humour then.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And I hope you are in the same still, you cannot change so soon.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Why, is it not a whole day ago?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What, are you not a day in the same humour?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Lord! that you who know the Town (they say) shou'd think any Woman could be a whole day together in an humour, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Hey! this begins to be pleasant: What, won't you go with me then after all?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir, I desire to be excus'd.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Then you have abus'd me all this while?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: It may be so.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Cou'd all that so natural Innocency be dissembl'd? Faith it cou'd not, dearest Miss.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Faith it was, dear Master.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Was it, faith?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Methinks you might believe me without an Oath: you saw I cou'd dissemble with my Father, why shou'd you think I cou'd not with you?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: So young a Wheadle?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Ay, a meer damn'd Jade I am.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And I have been abus'd, you say?

sp.speaker: Hipp▪
sp.p: 'Tis well you can believe it at last.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And I must never hope for you?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Wou'd you have me abuse you again?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Then you will not go with me?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: No; but for your comfort your loss will not be great, and that you may not resent it, for once I'll be ingenuous and disabuse you; I am no Heiress, as I told you to twelve hundred pound a year. I was only a lying Jade then, now you will part with me willingly I doubt not.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I wish I cou'd.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Come, now I find 'tis your turn to dissemble; but men use to dissemble for money, will you dissemble for nothing?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: 'Tis too late for me to dissemble.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Don't you dissemble, faith?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Nay, this is too cruel.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: What, wou'd you take me without the twelve hundred pound a year? wou'd you be such a Fool as to steal a Woman with nothing?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I'll convince you, for you shall go with me; and since you are twelve hundred pound a year the lighter, you'll be the easier carried away.

div.stage: He takes her in his Arms, she struggles.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: What, he takes her away against her will, I find I must knock for my Master then.

div.stage: Enter Don Diego and Mrs. Caution.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: My Father, my Father is here.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Prevented again!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What, you have done I hope now, Friend, for good and all?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Yes, yes, we have done for good and all indeed.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: How now! you seem to be out of humour, Friend.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Yes, so I am, I can't help it.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: He's a Dissembler in his very Throat, Brother.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Pray do not carry things so as to discover your self, if it be but for my sake, good Master.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: She is grown impudent.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: See, see, they whisper, Brother, to steal a Kiss under a Whisper, O the Harletry!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What's the matter, Friend?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: I say for my sake be in humour, and do not discover your self, but be as patient as a Dancing-master still.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What, she is whispering to him indeed! what's the matter? I will know it, Friend, look you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Will you know it?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Yes, I will know it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why, if you will know it, then she wou'd not do as I wou'd have her, and whisper'd me to desire me not to discover it to you.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What, Hussy, wou'd you not do as he'd have you! I'll make you do as he'd have you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I wish you wou'd.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: 'Tis a lye, she'll do all he'll have her do, and more too, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, tell me what 'twas then she wou'd not do, come do it, Hussy, or—Come, take her by the hand, Friend, come, begin, let's see if she will not do any thing now I am here.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Come, pray be in humour, Master.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I cannot dissemble like you.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What, she can't dissemble already, can she?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Yes but she can, but 'tis with you she dissembles; for they are not fallen out, as we think, for I'll be sworn I saw her just now give him the languishing Eye, as they call it, that is, the Whitings Eye, of old called the Sheeps Eye. I'll be sworn I saw it with these two Eyes, that I did.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: You'll betray us, have a care, good Master.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Hold your peace, I say, silly Woman.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: But does she dissemble already? how do you mean?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: She pretends she can't do what she shou'd do, and that she is not in humour, the common Excuse of Women for not doing what they shou'd do.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, I'll put her in humour; dance; I say, come, about with her, Master.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I am in a pretty humour to dance.
I cannot fool any longer, since you have fool'd me.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: You wou'd not be so ungenerous, as to betray the Woman that hated you, I do not do that yet; for Heaven's sake for this once be more obedient to my desires than your passion.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What is she humoursom still? But methinks you look your self as if you were in an ill humour; but about with her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I am in no good Dancing humour indeed.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Well, how goes the Dancing forward? what my Aunt here to disturb 'em again?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, come.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I say stand off, thou shalt not come near, avoid, Satan, as they say.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Nay then we shall have it, Nephew, hold her a little, that she may not disturb 'em, come, now away with her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: One, two, and a Coupee.
Fool'd and abus'd.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Wilt thou lay violent hands upon thy own natural Aunt, Wretch?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, about with her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: One, two, three, four, and turn round.
By such a piece of Innocency.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Dost thou see, Fool, how he squeezes her hand?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: That won't do, Aunt.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Pray, Master, have patience, and let's mind our business.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Why did you anger him then, Hussy, look you?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Do you see how she smiles in his face, and squeezes his hand now?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Your Servant, Aunt, that won't do, I say.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Have patience, Master.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I am become her sport, one, two, three, Death, Hell, and the Devil.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ay, they are three indeed; but pray have patience.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Do you see how she leers upon him and clings to him, can you suffer it?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ay, ay.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: One, two, and a slur; can you be so unconcern'd after all?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What, is she unconcern'd! Hussy, mind your bus'ness.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: One, two, three, and turn round, one, two, fall back, Hell and Damnation.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ay, people fall back indeed into Hell and Damnation, Heav'n knows.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: One, two, three, and your Honour: I can fool no longer.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Nor will I be withheld any longer like a poor Hen in her Pen, while the Kite is carrying away her Chicken before her face.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What have you done? Well then let's see her dance it now to the Violin.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let's see her dance it to the Violin.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Another time, another time.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Don't you believe that, Friend; these Dancing-masters make no bones of breaking their words. Did not you promise just now I shou'd see her dance it to the Violin, and that I will too, before I stir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Let Monsieur play then while I dance with her, she can't dance alone.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I can't play at all, I'm but a Learner; but if you'll play, I'll dance with her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I can't play neither.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What a Dancing-master, and not play!

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Ay, you see what a Dancing-master he is. 'Tis as I told you, I warrant: A Dancing-master, and not play upon the Fiddle!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: O you have betray'd us all! if you confess that, you undo us for ever.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I cannot play, what wou'd you have me say?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I vow and swear we are all undone, if you cannot play.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What, are you a Dancing-master, and cannot play! umph—

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: He is only out of humour, Sir; here, Master, I know you will play for me yet, for he has an excellent hand.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ay, that he has.
At giving a box on the Ear.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Why does he not play then?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Here, Master, pray play for my sake.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What wou'd you have me do with it? I cannot play a stroke.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: No, stay then, seem to tune it, and break the strings.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Come then.
Next to the Devil's the Invention of Women, they'll no more want an excuse to cheat a Father with, than an opportunity to abuse a Husband.
But what do you give me such a damn'd Fiddle with rotten strings for?

div.stage: Winds up the strings till they break, and throws the Violin on the ground.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Hey-day, the Dancing-master is frantick.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, that people shou'd be made such Fools of.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: He broke the strings on purpose, because he cou'd not play, you are blind, Brother.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What, will you see further than I? look you.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: But pray, Master, why in such haste?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Because you have done with me.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: But don't you intend to come to morrow agen?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Your Daughter does not desire it.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: No matter, I do, I must be your pay Master I'm sure, I wou'd have you come betimes too, not only to make her perfect; but since you have so good a hand upon the Violin to play your part with half a dozen of Musicians more, whom I wou'd have you bring with you; for we will have a very merry Wedding, though a very private one; you'll be sure to come?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Your Daughter does not desire it.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, come, Baggage, you shall desire it of him, he is your Master.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: My Father will have me desire it of you, it seems.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But you'll make a Fool of me agen: if I shou'd come, wou'd you not?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: If I shou'd tell you so, you'd be sure not to come.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, come, she shall not make a Fool of you, upon my word: I'll secure you, she shall do what you'll have her.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, so, so, silly Don.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But, Madam, will you have me come?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: I'd have you to know for my part, I care not whether you come or no; there are other Dancing-masters to be had, it is my Fathers request to you: all that I have to say to you, is a little good advice, which (because I will not shame you) I'll give you in private.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: What, will you let her whisper with him too?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Nay, if you find fault with it, they shall whisper; though I did not like it before, I'll ha' no body wiser than my self; but do you think if 'twere any hurt, she wou'd whisper it to him before us?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: If it be no hurt, why does she not speak aloud?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Because she says she will not put the man out of Countenance.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Hey-day, put a Dancing-master out of countenance!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: You say he is no Dancing-master.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Yes, for his impudence, he may be a Dancing-master.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Well, well, let her whisper before me as much as she will to night, since she is to be marry'd to morrow, especially since her Husband that shall be stands by consenting too.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let 'em whisper (as you say) as much as they will before we marry. She's making more sport with him, I warrant; but I wonder how people can be fool'd so, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Well, a Penny for the secret, Daughter.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Indeed, Father, you shall have it for nothing to morrow.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Well, Friend, you will not fail to come.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No, no, Sir.
Yet I am a Fool, if I do.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: And be sure you bring the Fiddlers with you, as I bid you.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Yes, be sure you bring the Fiddlers with you, as I bid you.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: So, so, He'll fiddle your Daughter out of the House, must you have Fiddles, with a fiddle, faddle.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Lord! that people shou'd be made such Fools of, hah, hah.

div.stage: Ex. Don, Hipp. Mons. Caut. and Prue.

lg.l: Fortune we sooner may than Woman trust
To her considing Gallant she is just;
But falser Woman only him deceives,
Who to her Tongue and Eyes most credit gives.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur and Black stalking over the Stage, to them Mr. Gerard.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: GOod morrow to thee, noble Dancing-master, ha, ha, ha, your little black Brother here, my Master, I see, is the more diligent man of the two; but why do you come so late? what you begin to neglect your Scholar, do you? Little black Master (con Licentia) pray get you out of the Room.
What, out of humour, Man! a Dancing-master shou'd be like his Fiddle, always in Tune. Come, my Cousin has made an Ass of thee, what then, I know it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Does he know it?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: But prethee don't be angry, 'twas agreed upon betwixt us, before I sent you, to make a Fool of thee, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Was it so?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I knew you would be apt to entertain vain hopes from the Summons of a Lady; but faith the design was but to make a Fool of thee, as you find.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: 'Tis very well.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: But indeed I did not think the Jest wou'd have lasted so long, and that my Cousin wou'd have made a Dancing-master of you, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: The Fool has reason, I find, and I am the Coxcomb while I thought him so.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Come, I see you are uneasie, and the Jest of being a Dancing-master grows tedious to you; but have a little patience, the Parson is sent for, and when once my Cousin and I are marry'd, my Uncle may know who you are.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I am certainly abus'd.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: What do you say?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Meerly fool'd.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Why do you doubt it? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Can it be?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Pish, pish, she told me yesterday as soon as you were gone, that she had led you into a Fools Paradise, and made you believe she wou'd go away with you, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Did she so? I am no longer to doubt it then?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ay, ay, she makes a meer Fool of thee, I vow and swear; but don't be concern'd, there's hardly a man of a thousand but has been made a Fool of by some Woman or other: I have been made a Fool of my self, man, by the Women, I have, I vow and swear, I have.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Well, you have, I believe it, for you are a Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p:
Lord! you need not be so touchy with one, I tell you but the truth for your good, for though she does, I wou'd not fool you any longer; but prethee don't be troubl'd at what can't be help'd. Women are made on purpose to fool men; when they are Children, they fool their Fathers; and when they
