have taken their leaves of their Hanging-sleeves, they fool their Gallants or Dancing-masters, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Hark you, Sir, to be fool'd by a Woman you say is not to be help'd; but I will not be fool'd by a Fool.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: You shew your English breeding now, an English Rival is so dull and brutish as not to understand raillery, but what is spoken in your passion, I'll take no notice of, for I am your Friend, and would not have you my Rival to make your self ridiculous. Come, prethee, prethee, don't be so concern'd; for as I was saying, Women first fool their Fathers, then their Gallants, and then their Husbands; so that it will be my turn to be fool'd too; (for your comfort) and when they come to be Widows, they would fool the Devil I vow and swear. Come, come, dear Gerard, prethee don't be out of humour and look so sillily.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Prethee do not talk so sillily.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nay, faith I am resolv'd to beat you out of this ill humour.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Faith, I am afraid I shall first beat you into an ill humour.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, that thou should'st be gull'd so by a little Gipsey, who left off her Bib but yesterday; faith I can't but laugh at thee.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Faith then I shall make your mirth (as being too violent) conclude in some little mis-fortune to you. The Fool begins to be tyrannical.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, poor angry Dancing-Master; prethee match my Spanish pumps and legs with one of your best and newest Sarabands; ha, ha, ha, come—

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I will match your Spanish Ear, thus, Sir, and make you Dance thus.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: How! sa, sa, sa, then I'll make you Dance thus.
sp.stage: Mon. draws his Sword and runs at him, but Ger. drawing her retires.
sp.p: Hold, hold a little: A desperate disappointed Lover will cut his own throat, then sure he will make nothing of cutting his Rivals throat.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Consideration is an Enemy to fighting; if you have a mind to revenge your self, your Sword's in your hand.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, hold your peace; I'll ne'er take my Rivals counsel be't what 'twill, I know what you wou'd be at; you are disappointed of your Mistress, and cou'd hang yourself, and therefore will not fear hanging; but I am a successful Lover, and need neither hang for you nor my Mistress; nay, if I should kill you, I know I should do you a kindness; therefore e'en live to die daily with envy of my happiness; but if you will needs die, kill your self and be damn'd for me I vow and swear.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But won't you sight for your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I tell you, you shall not have the honour to be kill'd for her; besides, I will not be hit in the teeth by her as long as I live with the great love you had for her. Women speak well of their dead Husbands, what will they do of their dead Gallants?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But if you will not fight for her, you shall Dance for her, since you desir'd me to teach you to Dance too; I'l teach you to Dance thus—

div.stage: Strikes his Sword at his legs, Monsieur leaps.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nay, if it be for the sake of my Mistress, there's nothing I will refuse to do.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Nay, you must Dance on.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ay, ay, for my Mistress and Sing too, la, la, la, ra, la.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: What Swords drawn betwixt you two? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Is she here?
Come put up your Sword; you see this is no place for us; but the Devil eat me, if you shall not eat my Sword, but—

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: What's the matter, Cousin?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing, Cousin; but your presence is a Sanctuary for my greatest Enemy, or else, teste non.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: What, you have not hurt my Cousin, Sir, I hope?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How she's concern'd for him; nay, then I need not doubt, my fears are true.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: What was that you said, Cousin! hurt me, ha, ha, ha, hurt me! if any man hurt me, he must do it basely; he shall ne'er do it when my Sword's drawn, sa, sa, sa.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Because you will ne'er draw your Sword perhaps.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Scurvily guess'd.
You Ladies may say any thing; but, Cousin, pray do not you talk of Swords and fighting, meddle with your Guitar, and talk of dancing with your Dancingmaster there, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: But I am afraid you have hurt my Master, Cousin, he says nothing; can he draw his breath?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: No, 'tis you have hurt your Master, Cousin, in the very heart, Cousin, and therefore he wou'd hurt me; for Love is a disease makes people as malicious as the Plague does.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Indeed, poor Master, something does all you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Cousin, faith don't abuse him any longer, he's an honest Gentleman, and has been long of my acquaintance, and a man of tolerable sense to take him out of his Love; but prethee, Cousin, don't drive the Jest too far for my sake.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: He counsels you well, pleasant-cunning-jilting-Miss for his sake; for if I am your divertisement, it shall be at his cost, since he's your Galiant in favour.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: I don't understand you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: But I do, a pox take him, and the Custom that so orders it, forsooth; that if a Lady abuse or affront a man, presently the Gallant must be beaten, nay, what's more unreasonable, if a Woman abuse her Husband, the poor Cuckold must bear the shame as well as the injury.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: But what's the matter, Master? what was it you said?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I say pleasant, cunning, jilting Lady, though you make him a Cuckold, it will not be revenge enough for me upon him for marrying you.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: How, my surly, hussing, jealous, sensless sawcy Master?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nay, nay, faith give losers leave to speak, losers of Mistresses especially, ha, ha, ha. Besides, your anger is too great a favour for him, I scorn to honour him with mine, you see.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: I tell you, my sawey Master, my Cousin shall never be made that monstrous thing (you mention) by me.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Thank you, I vow and swear, Cousin, no, no, I never thought I should.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Sure you marry him by the sage Maxime of your Sex, which is, Wittals make the best Husbands, that is, Cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Indeed, Master, whatsoever you think, I wou'd sooner chuse you for that purpose than him.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, there she was with him, i'faith, I thank you for that, Cousin, I vow and swear.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Nay, he shall thank me for that too; but how came you two to quarrel? I thought, Cousin, you had had more wit than to quarrel, or more kindness for me than to quarrel here: what if my Father hearing the Bustle shou'd have come in, he wou'd soon have discover'd our false Dancing-master (for passion un-masks every man) and then the result of your quarrel had been my ruine.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nay, you had both felt his desperate, deadly, daunting Dagger; there are your dès for you.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Go, go, presently therefore, and hinder my Father from coming in, whilst I put my Master into a better humour, that we may not be discover'd, to the prevention of our Wedding, or worse, when he comes, go, go.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Well, well, I will, Cousin.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Be sure you let him not come in this good while.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: No, no, I warrant you.
But if he shou'd come before I wou'd have him, I'll come before him and cough and hawk soundly, that you may not be susprised. Won't that do well, Cousin?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Very well, pray be gone.

Well, Master, since I find you are quarrelsom and melancholy, and wou'd have taken me away without a Portion, three infallible signs of a true Lover, Faith here's my hand now in earnest, to lead me a Dance as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How's this? you surprise me as much as when first I found so much Beauty and Wit in Company with so much Innocency. But, Dearest, I would be assur'd of what you say, and yet dare not ask the question. You h—do not abuse me again, you h—will fool me no more sure.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Yes but I will sure.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How! nay, I was afraid on't.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: For I say you are to be my Husband, and you say Husbands must be Wittals, and some strange things to boot.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Well, I will take my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: But have a care, rash man.

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.p: I will venture.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: At your peril, remember I wish'd you to have a care, fore-warn'd, forearm'd.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Indeed now that's fair; for most men are fore-arm'd before they are warn'd.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Plain dealing is some kind of honesty however, and few Women wou'd have said so much.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: None but those who wou'd delight in a Husbands jealousie, as the proof of his love and her honour.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, let us have a good understanding betwixt one another at first, that we may be long Friends; I differ from you in the point, for a Husbands jealousie, which cunning men wou'd pass upon their Wives for a Complement, is the worst can be made 'em, for indeed it is a Complement to their Beauty, but an affront to their Honour.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But, Madam—

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: So that upon the whole matter I conclude, jealousie in a Gallant is humble true Love, and the height of respect, and only an undervaluing of himself to overvalue her; but in a Husband 'tis arrant sawciness, cowardise, and ill breeding, and not to be suffer'd.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I stand corrected, gracious Miss.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Well! but have you brought the Gentlemen Fidlers with you as I desired?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: They are below.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Are they arm'd well?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Yes, they have Instruments too that are not of wood; but what will you do with them?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: What did you think I intended to do with them? when I whisper'd you to bring Gentlemen of your acquaintance instead of Fidlers, as my Father desir'd you to bring pray what did you think I intended?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Faith, e'en to make fools of the Gentlemen-Fidlers, as you had done of your Gentleman Dancing-Master.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: I intended 'em for our guard and defence against my Fathers Spanish and Guiney force, when we were to make our retreat from hence, and to help us to take the Keys from my Aunt, who has been the watchful Porter of this House this twelve-month; and this design (if your heart do not fail you) we will put in execution, as soon as you have given your friends below instructions.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Are you sure your heart will stand right still? you flinch'd last night, when I little expected it, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: The time last night was not so proper for us as now, for reasons I willgive you; but besides that, I confess, I had a mind to try whether your interest did not sway you more than your love; whether the twelve hundred pounds a year I told you of, had not made a greater impression in your heart than Hippolita; but finding it otherwise—yet hold, perhaps upon consideration you are grown wiser; can you yet, as I said, be so desperate, so out of fashion, as to steal a Woman with nothing?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: With you I can want nothing, nor can be made by any thing more rich or happy.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Think well again; can you take me without the twelve hundred pounds a year; the twelve hundred pounds a year?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Indeed, Miss, now you begin to be unkind again, and use me worse than e'er you did.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Well, though you are so modest a Gentleman as to suffer a Wife to be put upon you with nothing, I have more Conscience than to do it: I have the twelve hundred pounds a year out of my Father's power, which is yours, and I am sorry it is not the Indies to mend your bargain.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Dear Miss, you but encrease my fears, and not my wealth: pray let us make haste away, I desire but to be secure of you; come, what are you thinking of?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: I am thinking if some little filching inquisitive Poet shou'd get my story, and represent it on the Stage; what those Ladies, who are never precise but at a Play, wou'd say of me now; that I were a confident coming piece, I warrant, and they wou'd damn the poor Poet for libelling the Sex; but sure though I give my self and fortune away frankly, without the consent of my Friends, my confidence is less than theirs, who stand off only for separate maintenance.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: They wou'd be Widows before their time, have a Husband and no Husband: but let us be gone, lest fortune shou'd recant my happiness. Now you are fix'd, my dearest Miss.

div.stage: Enter Monsieur coughing, and Don Diego.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Oh here's my Father!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: How now, Sir! what kissing her hand? what means that, Friend, ha! Daughter, ha! do you permit this insolence, ha! (voto à mi honrâ.)

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: We are prevented again.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, you are so full of your Spanish Jealousie, Father, why you must know he's a City Dancing-master, and they, forsooth, think it fine to kiss the hand at the Honour before the Corant.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ay, Uncle, don't you know that?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Go to, go to, you are an easie French Fool, there's more in it than so, look you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I vow and swear there's nothing more in't, if you'll believe one. Did not I cough and hawk? a jealous prudent Husband cou'd not cough and hawk louder at the approach of his Wifes Chamber in visiting-time, and yet you wou'd not hear me, he'll make now ado about nothing, and you'll be discover'd both.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Umph, umph, no, no, I see it plain, he is no Dancing-master, now I have found it out, and I think I can see as far into matters as another: I have found it now, look you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: My fear was prophetical.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: What shall we do? nay, pray, Sir, do not stir yet.

div.stage: Ger offers to go out with her.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: What's the matter, Brother? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I have found it out, Sister, I have found it out, Sister, this Villain here is no Dancing-master, but a dishonourer of my House and Daughter, I caught him kissing her hand.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Pish, pish, you are a strange Spanish kind of an Uncle, that you are, a dishonourer of your Daughter, because he kissed her hand; pray how cou'd he honour her more? he kiss't her hand, you see, while he was making his Honour to her.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p:
You are an unthinking, shallow, French Fop, voto—But I tell you, Sister, I have thought of it, and have found it out, he is no Dancing-master,
Sister. Do you remember the whispering last night? I have found out the meaning of that too, and I tell you, Sister, he's no Dancing-master, I have found it out.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: You found it out, marry come up, did not I tell you always he was no Dancing-master?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: You tell me, you silly Woman, what then? what of that? you tell me, de' think I heeded what you told me? but I tell you now I have found it out.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I say I found it out.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I say 'tis false, Gossip, I found him out.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I say I found him out first, say you what you will.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Sister Mum, not such a word again, guarda—you found him out.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Nay, I must submit, or dissemble like other prudent Women, or—

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, come, Sister, take it from me, he is no Dancing-master.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: O yes, he is a Dancing-master.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What will you be wiser than I every way? remember the whispering, I say.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: So, he thinks I speak in earnest, then I'll fit him still.
But what do you talk of their whispering, they wou'd not whisper any ill before us sure.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Will you still be an Idoit, a Dolt, and see nothing.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Lord! you'll be wiser than all the World, will you? are we not all against you? pshaw, pshaw, I ne'er saw such a Donissimo as you are, I vow and swear.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: No, Sister, he's no Dancing-master; for now I think on't too, he cou'd not play upon the Fiddle.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Pish, pish, what Dancing-master can play upon a Fiddle without strings?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Again, I tell you he broke 'em on purpose, because he cou'd not play; I have found it out now, Sister.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Nay, you see farther than I, Brother.

div.stage: Ger. offers to lead her out.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake stir not yet.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Besides, if you remember they were perpetually putting me out of the Room, that was, Sister, because they had a mind to be alone, I have found that out too: Now, Sister, look you, he is no Dancing-master.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: But has he not given her a Lesson often before you.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I but, Sister, he did not go about his bus'ness like a Dancing-master; but go, go down to the door, some body rings.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I vow and swear Uncle he is a Dancing-master; pray be appeas'd, Lord d'e think I'd tell you a lye?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: If it prove to be a lye, and you do not confess it, though you are my next Heir after my Daughter, I will disown thee as much as I do her, for thy folly and treachery to thy self, as well as me; you may have her, but never my estate look you

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: How! I must look to my hits then.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Look to't.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Then I had best confess all, before he discover all, which he will soon do.
O here's the Parson too! he won't be in choler nor brandish Toledo before the Parson sure?
Well, Uncle, I must confess, rather than lose your favour, he is no Dancingmaster.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What has the Fool betray'd us then at last? nay, then 'tis time to be gone; come away, Miss.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, if you pass this way, my Toledo will pass that way, look you.

div.stage: Thrusts at him with his Sword.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: O hold, Mr. Gerrard, hold, Father!

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I tell you Uncle he's an honest Gentleman, means no hurt, and came hither but upon a frolick of mine and your Daughters.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ladron, Traidor.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I tell you all's but a jest, a meer jest I vow and swear.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: A jest, jest with my honour voto, ha! no Family to dishonour but the Grave, Wise, Noble, Honourable, Illustrious, Puissant, and right Worshipful Family of the Formals; nay, I am contented to reprieve you, till you know who you have dishonoured, and convict you of the greatness of your crime before you die, we are descended, look you—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nay, pray Uncle hear me.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I say, we are descended.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter for that.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: And my great, great, Grandfather was.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Well, well, I have something to say more to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: My great, great, great Grandfather, I say, was—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Well, a Pin-maker in—

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: But he was a Gentleman for all that, Fop, for he was a Serjeant to a Company of the Train-bands, and my great, great, great Grandfather was.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Was his Son, what then? won't you let me clear this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: He was, he was—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: He was a Felt-maker, his Son a Wine cooper, your Father a Vintner, and so you came to be a Canary-Merchant.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: But we were still Gentlemen, for our Coat was as the Heralds say—was—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Was, your sign was the Three Tuns, and the Field Canary; now let me tell you this honest Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Now that you shou'd dare to dishonour this Family; by the Graves of my Ancestors in Great Saint Ellen's Church—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Yard.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Thou shalt dye for't, ladron.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Uncle, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nay then, by your own Spanish rules of honour (though he be my Rival) I must help him, since I brought him into danger.
Sure he will not shew his valour upon his Nephew and Son-in-Law, otherwise I shou'd be afraid of shewing mine.

Here Mr. Gerrard, go in here, nay, you shall go in, Mr. Gerrard, I'll secure you all; and Parson do you go in too with 'em; for I see you are afraid of a Sword and the other World, though you talk of it so familiarly, and make it so fine a place.

div.stage: Opens a door, and thrusts Gerrard, Hippolita and Parson in, then shuts it, and guards it with his Sword.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Tu quoque, Brute.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nay, now Uncle you must understand reason; what, you are not only a Don, but you are a Don Quixot too, I vow and swear.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Thou spot, sploach of my Family and blood; I will have his blood, look you.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Pray good Spanish Uncle, have but patience to hear me; suppose—I say, suppose he had done, done, done the feat to your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: How, done the feat, done the feat, done the feat, En horâ malâ.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I say, suppose, suppose—

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Suppose—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: I say, suppose he had, for I do but suppose it; well, I am ready to marry her however; now Marriage is as good a Solder for crack'd Female-honour, as blood, and can't you suffer the shame but for a quarter of an-hour, till the Parson has marry'd us, and then if there be any shame, it becomes mine; for here in England, the Father has nothing to do with the Daughters business, honour, what de'e call't, when once she's marry'd, de'e see.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: England! what d'e tell me of England? I'll be a Spaniard still, voto à mi hora, and I will be reveng'd, Pedro, Juan, Sanches.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Caution follow'd by Flirt and Flounce in Vizard Masks.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: What's the matter, Brother?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Pedro, Sanchez, Juan, but who are these, Sister? are they not men in Womens Cloaths? what make they here?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: They are relations, they say, of my Cousins, who press'd in when I let in the Parson, they say my Cousin invited 'em to his Wedding.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Two of my relations, ha—they are my Cousins indeed of the other night; a Pox take 'em, but that's no Curse for 'em; a Plague take 'em then, but how came they here?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Now must I have witnesses too of the dishonour of my Family; it were Spanish Prudence to dispatch 'em away out of the House, before I begin my revenge.
What are you? what make you here? who wou'd you speak with?

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: With Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Here he is.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Now will these Jades discredit me, and spoil my match just in the coupling minute.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Do you know 'em?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, sure, I know 'em. Pray, Ladies, say as I say, or you will spoil my Wedding, for I am just going to be marry'd, and if my Uncle, or Mistress should know who you are, it might break off the match.

sp.speaker: Floun.
sp.p: We come on purpose to break the match.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Why, de'e think to marry and leave us so in the lurch?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: What do the Jades mean?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, who are they? what wou'd they have? if they come to the Wedding, Ladies, I assure you there will be none to day here.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: They won't trouble you, Sir, they are going again. Ladies, you hear what my Uncle says; I know you won't trouble him. I wish I were well rid of 'em.

sp.speaker: Floun.
sp.p: You shall not think to put us off so.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Who are they? what are their names?

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: We are, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nay, for Heaven's sake don't tell who you are, for you will undo me, and spoil my match infallibly.

sp.speaker: Floun.
sp.p: We care not, 'tis our business to spoil matches.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: You need not, for, I believe, marry'd men are your best customers, for greedy Batchellors take up with their Wives.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come, pray Ladies, if you have no business here, be pleas'd to retire, for few of us are in humour to be so civil to you, as you may deserve.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Ay, prethee dear Jades get you gone.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: We will not stir.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Who are they, I say, Fool, and why don't they go?

sp.speaker: Floun.
sp.p: We are, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Hold, hold.
They are persons of honour and quality, and—

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: We are no persons of honour and quality, Sir, we are—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: They are modest Ladies, and being in a kind of disguise, will not own their quality.

sp.speaker: Floun.
sp.p: We modest Ladies!

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Why? sometimes you are in the humour to pass for Women of honour and quality; prethee, dear Jades, let your modesty and greatness come upon you now.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Come, Sir, not to delude you, as he wou'd have us, we are—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Hold, hold—

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: The other night at the French House—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Hold, I say, 'tis even true as Gerrard says, the Women will tell, I see.

sp.speaker: Floun.
sp.p: If you wou'd have her silent, stop her mouth with that ring.

div.stage: Takes off his ring and gives it her.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Will that do't, here, here—
'Tis worth one hundred and fifty pounds;
But I must not lose my match, I must not lose a Trout for a Fly.
That Men shou'd live to hire Women to silence.

div.stage: Enter Gerrard, Hippolita, Parson and Prue.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Oh, are you come agen!

div.stage: Draws his Sword and runs at 'em, Monsieur holds him.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Oh, hold, hold, Uncle!
What are you mad, Gerrard, to expose your self to a new danger? why wou'd you come out yet?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Because our danger now is over, I thank the Parson there. And now we must beg—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nay, Faith, Uncle, forgive him now, since he asks you forgiveness upon his knees, and my poor Cousin too.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: You are mistaken, Cousin; we ask him blessing, and you forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: How, how, how! what do you talk of blessing? what do you ask your Father blessing, and he asks me forgiveness? But why shou'd he ask me forgiveness?

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Because he asks my Father blessing.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Pish, pish, I don't understand you, I vow and swear.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: The Parson will expound to you, Cousin.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Hey! what say you to it, Parson?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: They are marry'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Marry'd!

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Marry'd! so, I told you what 'twou'd come to.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: You told us—

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nay, she is setting up for the reputation of a Witch.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Marry'd, Juan, Sanchez, Petro, arm, arm, arm.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: A Witch, a Witch!

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: Nay, indeed Father, now we are marry'd, you had better call the Fiddles: Call 'em Prue quickly.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Who do you say marry'd, Man?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Was I not sent for on purpose to marry 'em? why shou'd you wonder at it?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: No, no, you were to marry me, Man, to her; I knew there was a mistake in't some how; you were meerly mistaken, therefore you must do your business over again for me now: The Parson was mistaken, Uncle, it seems, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I suppose five or six Guinies made him make the mistake, which will not be rectify'd now, Nephew; they'll marry all that come near 'em, and for a Guiney or two, care not what mischief they do, Nephew.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Marry'd, Pedro, Sanchez?

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: How, and must she be his Wife then for ever and ever? have I held the door then for this, like a Fool as I was?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Yes, indeed.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Have I worn Golillia here for this? little Breeches for this?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Yes, truly.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: And put on the Spanish honour with the habit, in defending my Rival; nay, then I'll have another turn of honour in revenge. Come, Uncle, I'm of your side now, sa, sa, sa, but let's stay for our force, Sanchez, Juan, Petro, arm, arm, arm.

div.stage: Enter two Blacks, and the Spaniard follow'd by Prue, Martin, and five other Gentlemen like Fiddlers.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Murder the Villain, kill him.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: How now, who sent for you, Friends?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: We Fiddlers, Sir, often come unsent for.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: And you are often kick'd down stairs for't too.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: No, Sir, our Company was never kick'd I think.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Fiddlers, and not kick'd? then to preserve your Virgin-honour, get you down stairs quickly; for we are not at present dispos'd much for mirth, voto.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: peeping. A pox, is it you, Martyn? nay, Uncle, then 'tis in vain; for they won't be kick'd down stairs, to my knowledge. They are Gentlemen Fiddlers, forsooth, a pox on all Gentlemen Fiddlers and Gentlemen Dancingmasters say I.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: How! ha.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Well, Flirt, now I am a Match for thee, now I may keep you, and there's little difference betwixt keeping a Wench and Marriage, only Marriage is a little the cheaper; but the other is the more honourable now, vert & bleu, nay now I may swear a French Oath too. Come, come, I am thine, let us strike up the Bargain, thine according to the honourable Institution of Keeping, come.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Nay hold, Sir, two words to the Bargain, first I have ne'er a Lawyer here to draw Articles and Settlements.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: How! is the World come to that? a Man cannot keep a Wench without Articles and Settlements, nay then 'tis e'en as bad as Marriage indeed, and there's no difference betwixt a Wife and a Wench.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Only in Cohabitation, for the first Article shall be against Cohabitation; we Mistresses suffer no Cohabitation.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Nor Wives neither now.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Then separate Maintenance, in case you shou'd take a Wife, or I a new Friend.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: How! that too? then you are every whit as bad as a Wife.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Then my House in Town, and yours in the Country, if you will.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: A meer Wife.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Then my Coach apart, as well as my Bed apart.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: As bad as a Wife still.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: But take notice I will have no little, dirty, second-hand Chariot new forbish'd, but a large, sociable, well painted Coach, nor will I keep it till it be as well known as my self, and it come to be call'd Flirt-Coach; nor will I have such pitiful Horses as cannot carry me every night to the Park; for I will not miss a night in the Park, I'd have you to know.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, you must have your great, gilt, fine, painted Coaches, I'm sure they are grown so common already amongst you, that Ladies of Quality begin to take up with Hackneys agen, Jarnie; but what else?

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Then, that you do not think I will be serv'd by a little dirty Boy in a Bonnet, but a couple of handsom, lusty, cleanly Footmen, sit to serve Ladies of Quality, and do their business as they shou'd do.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Then, that you never grow jealous of them.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Why will you make so much of them?

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: I delight to be kind to my Servants.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Well, is this all?

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: No then, that when you come to my House, you never presume to touch a Key, lift up a Latch, or thrust a Door, without knocking before hand; and that you ask no questions, if you see a stray Piece of Plate, Cabinet, or Looking-glass in my House.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Just a Wife in every thing; but what else?

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Then, that you take no acquaintance with me abroad, nor bring me home any when you are drunk, whom you will not be willing to see there, when you are sober.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: But what allowance? let's come to the main bus'ness, the money.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Stay, let me think, first for advance-money five hundred pounds for Pins.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: A very Wife.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Then you must take the Lease of my House, and furnish it as becomes one of my Quality; for don't you think we'll take up with your old Queen Elizabeth Furniture, as your Wives do.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Indeed there she is least like a Wife, as she says.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Then, for House-keeping, Servant-wages, Cloaths, and the rest, I'll be contented with a thousand pound a year present maintenance, and but three hundred pound a year separate maintenance for my life, when our Love grows cold; but I am contented with a thousand pound a year, because for Pendants, Neck-laces, and all sorts of Jewels, and such Trifles, nay and some Plate, I will shift my self as I can, make shifts, which you shall not take any notice of.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: A thousand pound a year! what will Wenching come to? Time was, a Man might have fared as well at a much cheaper rate; and a Lady of ones affections, instead of a House wou'd have been contented with a little Chamber three pair of Stairs backward, with a little Closet or Larder to't; and instead of variety of new Gowns and rich Petticoats, with her Dishabiliee or Flamecolour Gown call'd Indian, and Slippers of the same, wou'd have been contented for a twelve-month; and instead of Visits and gadding to Plays, wou'd have entertain'd her self at home with St. George for England, the Knight of the Sun, or the Practice of Piety; and instead of sending her Wine and Meat from the French-houses, wou'd have been contented, if you had given her (poor Wretch) but credit at the next Chandlers and Checker'd Cellar; and then instead of a Coach, wou'd have been well satisfi'd to have gone out and taken the Air for three or four hours in the Evening in the Balcony, poor Soul. Well, Flirt, however we'll agree; 'tis but three hundred pound a year separate maintenance, you say, when I am weary of thee and the Charge.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Rob'd of my Honour, my Daughter, and my Revenge too! Oh my dear Honour! nothing vexes me but that the World should say, I had not Spanish Policy enough to keep my Daughter from being debauch'd from me; but methinks my Spanish Policy might help me yet: I have it so—I will cheat 'em all; for I will declare I understood the whole Plot and Contrivance, and conniv'd at it, finding my Cousin a Fool, and not answering my expectation. Well; but then if I approve of the Match, I must give this Mock-Dancingmaster my Estate, especially since half he wou'd have in right of my Daughter, and in spight of me. Well, I am resolv'd to turn the Cheat upon themselves, and give them my Consent and Estate.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: Come, come, ne'er be troubl'd, Uncle, 'twas a Combination, you see, of all these Heads and your Daughters; you know what I mean, Uncle, not to be thwarted or govern'd by all the Spanish Policy in Christendom. I'm sure my French Policy wou'd not have govern'd her; so, since I have scap'd her, I am glad I have scap'd her, Jernie.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Come, Brother, you are wiser than I, you see, ay, ay.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: No, you think you are wiser than I now, in earnest; but know, while I was thought a Gull, I gull'd you all, and made them and you think I knew nothing of the Contrivance. Confess, did not you think verily, that I knew nothing of it, and that I was a Gull?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Yes indeed, Brother, I did think verily you were a Gull.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Alas, alas, all the sputter I made was but to make this Young man, my Cousin, believe, when the thing shou'd be effected, that it was not with my connivence or consent; but since he is so well satisfi'd, I own it. For do you think I wou'd ever have suffer'd her to marry a Monsieur, a Monsieur Guarda. Besides, it had been but a beastly incestuous kind of a Match, voto—

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Nay, then I see, Brother, you were wiser than I indeed.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: So, so.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Nay, Young-man, you have danc'd a fair Dance for your self royally, and now you may go jig it together till you are both weary; and though you were so eager to have him, Mrs. Minx, you'll soon have your belly-full of him, let me tell you, Mistress.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Hah, ha.

sp.speaker: Mons.
sp.p: How, Uncle! what was't you said? Nay if I had your Spanish Policy against me, it was no wonder I miss'd of my aim, mon foy.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I was resolv'd too, my Daughter shou'd not marry a Coward, therefore made the more ado to try you, Sir, but I find you are a brisk Man of Honour, firm, stiff, Spanish Honour; and that you may see I deceiv'd you all a long, and you not me; ay, and am able to deceive you still; for, I know, now you think that I will give you little or nothing with my Daughter (like other Fathers) since you have marry'd her without my consent; but, I say, I'll deceive you now, for you shall have the most part of my Estate in present, and the rest at my death; there's for you, I think I have deceiv'd you now, look you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No, indeed, Sir, you have not deceiv'd me, for I never suspected your love to your Daughter, nor your Generosity.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: How, Sir! have a care of saying I have not deceiv'd you, lest I deceive you another way; guarda—pray, Gentlemen, do not think any Man cou'd deceive me, look you; that any Man could steal my Daughter, look you, without my connivence.

lg.l: The less we speak, the more we think,
And he sees most, that seems to wink.

sp.speaker: Hipp.
sp.p: So, so, now I cou'd give you my blessing, Father, now you are à good complaisant Father, indeed.

lg.l: When Children marry, Parents shou'd obey,
Since Love claims more Obedience far than they.
THE Ladies first I am to Compliment,
Whom (if he cou'd) the Poet wou'd content,
But to their pleasure then they must consent.
Most spoil their sport still by their modesty,
And when they shou'd be pleas'd, cry out, O fie,
And the least smooty jest will ne'er pass by.
But City damsel ne'er had confidence,
At smooty Play to take the least offence,
But Mercy shews, to shew her innocence.
Yet lest the Merchants Daughters shou'd to day
Be scandaliz'd, not at our harmless Play;
But our Hippolita, since she's like one
Of us bold Flirts, of t'other end o' th' Town;
Our Poet sending to you (though unknown)
His best respects by me, do's frankly own
The character to be unnatural;
Hippolita is not like you at all;
You, while your Lovers court you, still look grum,
And far from wooing, when they woo, cry mum;
And if some of you e'er were stoll'n away,
Your Portion's fault 'twas only I dare say:
Thus much for him the Poet bid me speak,
Now to the men, I my own mind will break;
You good men o' th' Exchange, on whom alone
We must depend, when Sparks to Sea are gone;
Into the Pit already you are come,
'Tis but a step more to our Tyring room;
Where none of us but will be wondrous sweet
Upon an able Love of Lumber-street:
You we had rather see between our Scenes,
Than spend-thrift Fops with better Cloaths and meens;
Instead of Lac'd-coats, Belts, and Pantalloons,
Your Velvet Jumps, Gold Chains, and grave Fur Gowns,
Instead of Perriwigs, and broad cock'd Hats,
Your Sattin Caps, smalls Cuffs, and vast Crevats;
For you are fair and square in all your dealings,
You never cheat your Doxies with gilt Shillings;
You ne'er will break our Windows, then you are
Fit to make love, while our Houzaas make War;
And since all Gentlemen must pack to Sea,
Our Gallants, and our Judges you must be;
We therefore, and our Poet, do submit
To all the Chamlet Cloaks now i' the Pit.
